awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: A Multi-Network Architecture for Expanding Internet Participation and Community-Building on Native American Reservations
awd_abstract_narration:
Tribal communities represent the final frontiers of Internet access in the U.S., with fast (broadband) Internet access available to fewer than 10% of Native Americans on tribal reservation lands. The lack of broadband access is caused by a collection of challenges, including remote terrain, inadequate funding, and complex telecommunication policies. Yet Native Americans need reliable avenues for participation and contribution to Internet content to strengthen their communities. The work investigates technologies that will increase Internet availability on reservation lands using capacity that has been allocated to TV stations but is unused, so called ?white spaces?. Through the trial of our solutions within Southern California tribal communities, the work has the potential to reach over 2,700 homes and 60 community anchor institutions. While the immediate goal of the project is to benefit Native Americans throughout the U.S., the work has broad applicability beyond this context. Other indigenous groups, as well as low-income rural communities in the U.S. and elsewhere, face similar problems. Course material will be integrated from this project demonstrating the positive humanitarian impact of computer science in order to increase the appeal of computer science to female and minority groups. 

The goal of the research is to develop technologies to support Native American community building through broadening Internet accessibility and supporting social media content production and dissemination across the reservation. The work outlined in this proposal will make critical inroads to addressing the lack of Internet access on tribal reservations, to increase the number of Native American reservation residents who are able to engage with, create, and disseminate Internet and on-line social network content. The goal will be achieve through three related elements: (1) Development of an architecture suitable for a multi-network setting comprised of cellular, wireless ISP and whitespace networks, where coverage, cost and network speed varies. (2) Partnering with the community to pilot a next generation whitespace network on reservation lands, demonstrating geographic reach beyond current pilots and supporting quantitative measurements of changes in network use before and after deployment.  (3) Using  the initial lessons learned from the pilot to develop approaches to network management that span the socio-technical including, as appropriate, spectrum management, access management, caching policies and scheduled and on-demand content.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The goal of this project was to develop technologies to support Native American community building through broadening Internet accessibility and supporting social media content production and dissemination across the reservation. This project has made critical inroads to addressing the lack of Internet access on tribal reservations, to increase the number of Native American reservation residents who are able to engage with, create, and disseminate Internet and on-line social network content.

Intellectual Merit: This project facilitated the development of a multi-network architecture and the construction of a multi-network testbed at Georgia Tech (GT) that includes cellular, whitespace over cellular, and WiFi networking. The architecture also includes caches within the cellular infrastructure to facilitate content fetching during opportunistic contacts for later delivery to disconnected portions of reservation lands. UC Santa Barbara used the learnings from the GT portion of the testbed development to replicate and extend the system locally.

A second primary activity of this project consisted of close partnership with the Tribal Digital Village within the Southern California Tribal Chairmen?s Association in the evaluation and selection of TV whitespace (TVWS) network and user equipment. To support understanding of how whitespace-enabled connectivity affects users, we compiled research on relevant related work and developed empirical instruments for household Internet usage assessment. Our work on this grant resulted in multiple homes receiving Internet connectivity for the first time through TVWS network links.  The hardware selection and installation process, together with analysis of performance and usage of these links, has led to new insights on how this nascent technology can be readied for more widespread usage in rural and other sparsely populated regions.

Broader Impacts:  Tribal communities represent the final frontiers of Internet access in the U.S., with fast (broadband) Internet access available to fewer than 15% of Native Americans on tribal reservation lands. The lack of broadband access is caused by a collection of challenges, including remote terrain, inadequate funding, and complex telecommunication policies. Yet Native Americans need reliable avenues for participation and contribution to Internet content to strengthen their communities. Our work investigated technologies that will increase Internet availability on reservation lands using capacity that has been allocated to TV stations but is unused, so called ?white spaces?. Through the trial of our solutions within Southern California tribal communities, our work has the potential to reach over 2,700 homes and 60 community anchor institutions. Our goal is for our work to benefit Native Americans throughout the U.S., however our work has broad applicability beyond this context.  Other indigenous groups, as well as low-income rural communities in the U.S. and elsewhere, face similar problems.

Our work has contributed to the nascent scholarship on rural Internet and tribal social media use on Native American reservations. Through quantitative measurement we have been able to characterize connectivity from a client-centric point of view in carefully chosen locations (rather than relying, for example, on service provider reports of connectivity or crowdsourcing).  The work has contributed to the understanding of TVWS - its deployment, operation, management, and performance. It has also contributed to an understanding of how newer technologies such as white space networking can be used in conjunction with current technologies such as cellular and wireless ISPs to improve Internet access on Native American and other rural lands. Finally, homes on reservations within the Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association have Internet connectivity for the first time due to the installation of TV white space network links, funded through this award.

Many MS and PhD students were involved in the project. Prior to this work, none had experience with field-site data collection, either quantitative measurement work or qualitative interviewing work. For the students who have graduated, their skills and experience acquired in the research were important components of their job resume. Further, students learned how to meaningfully and respectfully engage with members of disenfranchised communities.  Finally, within our institutions, we have included in courses results from our research that demonstrate the positive humanitarian impact of computer science in order to increase the appeal of computer science to female and minority groups.
